{"title":"Section 2, Page 41","subjec":{},"descri":{},"creato":{},"publis":{},"date":{},"year":{},"format":{},"reposi":{},"collec":{},"reposa":{},"rights":{},"digitb":{},"langua":{},"topics":{},"cite":{},"notes":{},"notesa":{},"source":{},"box":{},"folder":{},"identi":{},"relati":{},"findin":{},"catalo":{},"type":{},"full":"41
Col, Payne informed the convention that he had
lately been called upon by a number of merchants
from Texas on their way north, who were directed
to assure him that if the road were constructed to
the Texas border, the legislature of their state would
he favorably disposed to a prolongation of the improvement into the heart of their commonwealth.—
With the view of quickeuing this spirit, aud enabling
the legislature of Texas to comprehend the extent
to which the interests of their constituents were involved, the Colonel suggested that an agent should
be appointed by the convention to visit Texas, and
canvass the slate, and impress upon the legislature
flic importance of its co-operation. That the immediate object of this convention was the extension
of the New Orleans, Algiers, Attakapas and Opelousas Railroad to the Texas line, with a view to
cress her beautiful domain to El Passo, and thence
to the Pacific. That it was eminently the interest
ol this convention, and of the State of Louisiana,
to enlist the sympathies of the people of Texas in
its favor; that the resolutions of Mr Burke should
lie so amended, as to give ihe principal direction of
the labors, of the proposed coirfmittee, to Texas,
and to invite the people and public authorities to
unite with us in carrying forward this gigantic work
to Sau Diego and San Francisco on the Pacific.—
Without such an amendment, the resolutions, in his
°pinion, ought not to passs ; with it, he hoped they
would.
